did.abstract: Author and political consultant from Charlotte, Michigan who wrote a book on the Milo Radulovich Case; records include interviews, correspondence, newspaper clippings, Radulovich military records, research notes, and documentation relating to the writing and publication of To Strike at a King: The Turning Point in the McCarthy Witch-Hunt.

bioghist.p: Michael Ranville (born December 3, 1943), is author of the book To Strike at a King: The Turning Point in the McCarthy Witch Hunt. He is a native of Flint, Michigan and a former political consultant. Ranville received his bachelor's degree from Central Michigan University before joining the United States Air Force in 1966. He served in the Air Force until 1970, where he provided air-to-ground communication to the President of the United States and other high-ranking American officials from Andrews Air Force Base.

Following his time in the Air Force, Ranville returned to school to earn a master's degree in communications at Central Michigan University. He then began a career in public relations and free-lance speechwriting. In 1976, he accepted a research and speech writing position in the Michigan State Senate. Eventually, Ranville left this position to join the lobbying firm Karoub Associates.

Ranville has authored a number of magazine and newspapers articles dealing with history, politics, sports, and public relations, however, he is probably best known for his book To Strike at a King about Milo Radulovich.

Milo John Radulovich (October 28, 1926 -- November 19, 2007) was an American citizen (born in Detroit) of Montenegrin descent who served as a lieutenant in the Air Force reserve in the 1950s. In 1953, the Air Force accused him of being a security risk for maintaining a "close and continuing relationship" with his father and sister who had been identified as possible "security risks." The Air Force stripped him of his commission under the provisions of Air Force Regulation 35-62. Radulovich was eventually reinstated, but only after Edward R. Murrow brought Radulovich's case to the nation's attention on the television news program "See It Now" on October 20, 1953.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of six series: Milo Radulovich Research materials, Writing and Publicity, Later Milo Radulovich materials, Other articles, Video materials, Sound materials, and Posters. The collection's strength lies in Ranville's interviews with Milo, his sister, and other's involved in Radulovich's Air Force Security Hearing, as well as in the other accumulated research materials.

scopecontent.p: The Milo Radulovich Research materials series documents Ranville's research for his book. The series contains interviews, newspaper clippings, correspondence, photocopies of Radulovich's military records, and Ranville's research notes.

odd.p: (includes retrospective articles about the Radulovich case)

scopecontent.p: The Writing and Publicity series documents Ranville's writing and editing process as well as publicity efforts for his book. It contains drafts of various chapters, copyediting documents, correspondence, and publicity materials. The publicity materials mostly include correspondence, book reviews, and publicity materials related to Ranville's interviews, lectures, and book signings.

The Later Milo Radulovich materials series documents some of the publicity surrounding the film "Good Night, and Good Luck," and efforts to honor Radulovich from the mid-1990s to 2008. It contains copies of screenplays for the film, newspaper and magazine publicity, and materials involving efforts to honor Radulovich, including documents related to the posthumous Bachelor of Arts ceremony at the Bentley Historical Library in 2008.

scopecontent.p: The Other articles series contains two articles written by Michael Ranville that are unrelated to Milo Radulovich.

The Video materials series contains a series of video cassettes related to Milo Radulovich and McCarthyism. Most of the cassettes pertain to Ranville's research for To Strike at a King, including a copy of the episode of "See It Now" that highlighted Radulovich's case. The series also contains cassettes of Ranville's speeches and interviews after publication of the book.
